para.emphasis: Update graphics, insert publication and conclusion
Updated Doc and Publication digarms and some minor editorial updates
Final Sign-off of Source Document In SharePoint by Project Team.
Converted to DocBook XML for wider re-use

listitem.para: 1. We have taken the approach of modelling the semantic and structural components of a document separately in order to encourage modularity, simplicity and reuse where many semantic entities will follow the same structural model. We have also separated the modelling of the content of documents themselves from their components. This allows us to create a logical document model that encompasses all of the semantic components of OECD documents without need to reference specific document types. Additionally, the semantic content can be described and implemented in terms of the structural components.

2. The wide range of content analysed during the content analysis stage of the project and the results of the document assembly and modelling workshops has provided a large number of semantic components and a solid overview of the structural components of documents.

3. The separation of these parts of the model will allow the creation of new document models (document types) to be a matter of choosing the correct components and defining their relationships and cardinality within that model. The exact relationships and the cardinality of those relationships are part of the schema design process – the document model simply identifies that there is a relationship.
4. Document types discovered as part of the document modelling and analysis processes are listed in Appendix A of this document.

5. Five groups of components (Semantic, Structural, Block, Inline and Metadata) make up the component catalogue for the model. Document types compose this catalogue into concrete models for use in document creation. Editorial and publishing enrichment components are beyond the scope of this modelling exercise. The models and components discussed could be extended to support these types of requirements.
6. In order to ensure that this document is internally consistent and in order to ensure that the meaning of this document is shared we use the following definitions throughout this document.

7. A document model is the top level output of the modeling process. It describes the components available to a particular document type (as identified during the workshops) and the relationship between the components of that document type.

8. A component is a logical construct representing a portion of a document. Components are generally recursive structures containing other components. Components can represent both structural entities in a document (such as a paragraph) and semantic entities (such as an abstract).
9. A standard term used to describe the child components of a parent component and the relationships between them.

sect1.para: The diagrams show relationships between components. No cardinality is implied. Blue lines indicate parent child relationships. Grey lines indicate 'type-of' relatonships (the arrow leads from the derived type to the supertype). Green boxes indicate groups or group members and blue boxes components.

listitem.para: 10. The scope of the OECD.Author document-modelling project is limited to the analysis and modelling of narrative official documents and publications.

11. The development process began with extensive document analysis based on a corpus of official documents (with multiple language translations of the same document removed) covering a two-year period. This produced approximately 28,000 documents for analysis.
12. The document analysis helped identify some of the document types and most of the initial component list that was used as an input to the initial workshop with document assemblers.

13. This model has been developed primarily through the use of workshops to gain consensus on the structure and content of OECD documents. The Assemblers Workshop (p) involving OECD staff involved in the construction and editing of official documents led to the creation of an initial list of document components. Additionally, the attendees of the initial workshop refined the document type list.

14. The Technical Workshop (p)was intended to reach consensus on two groups of topics. Firstly, we needed to agree the base technologies to be used for the model and any existing models to be used as components of the OECD.Author model. Secondly, some agreement needed to be made on the technical governance of this model.
15. The technical approach to modelling is discussed below (Technical Approach). Governance issues will be discussed in a separate document.

16. The semantic components identified represent those meaningful parts of a document that may be found in one or more document types. In most cases they can be viewed as specialisations of the generic section concept discussed below. These components include both OECD specific concepts such as ‘mandate’ and traditional publishing concepts such as ‘chapter’. However, many of these can be viewed as structural sections (see ). It is envisaged that specialisations would occur at the schema implementation level through type inheritance.

17. A semantic component is one which carries an additional meaningful load, over and above, that provided by the structure and formatting of the text. That is, there is an overlay of meaning added to the base textual structure.
Abstract
Acknowledgements
Executive summary
Foreword
Paragraph group
Amendments
Recommendations
Introduction
Preface
Guidelines
Action Required
Comments
Country/Delegate Comments
General Comments
Summary
Position
Note to Delegates
Bibliographic References (and related components)

18. These components were primarily generated from the document analysis project and the document assemblers workshop. Some of the initial outputs of the analysis project (such as Press Releases) have been removed at the suggestion of the document assembly workshop. Additional components will be defined through normal business governance processes.
19. Models for generic semantic components can be usually be viewed as variants on the diagram below
Extracts
Notes
Document List
Document Reference
Agenda Session
Agenda Item
Action
Conclusion

sect2.para: The notes component was originally defined as notes specific to tables, figures and boxes by the modelling workshop. Nic Gibson has proposed that the component is generalised to represent any block note group without the particular semantics of a footnote (or endnote).

listitem.para: 20. Some of these semantic components have particular constraints (for example, an executive summary is constrained by length and limited to contain block components only). Some, however, can be considered to be unconstrained sections with only metadata (and, often, a predefined title) to define the distinction. For example, a preface has no particular constraints on content but occupies a distinct semantic role. Table 1 attempts to indicate whether or not any individual semantic component has constraints on it.

sect2.para:
Table – Semantic Components
It is beyond the scope of this project to determine the unknown constraints where these are applicable to a very limited number of document types. The model framework allows these to be added as they are analysed.

entry.para:
Currently paragraphs only
This needs to be discussed with ECO authors who may have a need to include other components (e.g. Charts, Tables) in an Executive Summary.

listitem.para: 21. The primary structural component used in OECD documents is the section. For the purposes of this modelling exercise a section is defined as:
An optional title followed a sequence of one or more structural or block level components that can be viewed as an individual unit.
22. In existing documents almost all sections have a title. Those without a title are a small subset. Currently, only ‘abstract’ has been defined as not having a title.

23. This primary structural component can be broken into two subsets – simple and recursive. The simple components may not contain themselves directly. Recursive components may contain themselves as shown in Figure 2.

24. The generic section component is recursive. A simpler section component will probably be implemented during the creation of any implementation schema because it will be difficult to constrain the recursive content model appropriately.

sect1.para: Figure 3 - Generic Section Component

listitem.para: Document
Chapter
Section

25. The Document component is defined on a per document model basis. The general OECD.Author document model consists of chapters; in other models it may be more constrained (in an agenda, for example), or more rich (in a publication with parts, for example).
26. Chapters, Prefaces, Introductions and Appendixes have very similar content models. The semantic components are based on the structural chapter component.

27. The components below were defined during the Modelling Workshops. It was felt that they may be superfluous but they have beed added as sections with associated metadata now and can be changed or removed later if required.
28. The publishing components represent the additional structural requirements of some published documents.
29. Publishing components are:
Part
Volume
Chapter

30. Block components represent various ways of structuring blocks of text. Semantically, most of the blocks are interchangeable. One of the major determinants when deciding a component should be considered a structural or block component is the answer to the question "Can this component contain other structural components?" If this is not the case, we consider it a block component. The distinction can be difficult at the border between the two. Another question to be asked is "Can this component be replaced by another without destroying the structure of the document?" If this is the case, we consider it a block component.
31. Block components identified so far are given below:
Paragraphs
Formal Paragraphs
Paragraph Groups
Lists (Ordered, Itemized and Definition)
Tables
Figures
Graphics
Boxes
Block Equations (seen Inline components)
Block Chemical Structures (see Inline components)
32. Certain semantic components also have block features:
Extracts
Notes

33. For the purpose of modelling, block components and sections have been divided into two groups. The modelling diagrams use these groups in order to reduce complexity. These components are reused throughout the document model.
34. Simple blocks are those block components that do not allow recursion. These are defined as:
Paragraphs
Formal Paragraphs
Ordered lists
Itemized lists
Definition Lists
Figures
Graphics
Boxes
Paragraph groups
35. Nested blocks are those components listed above plus tables.
36. The inline content model describes text that exists as block item content and as simple phrasal content. Inline content is running text, title text, etc.

37. The inline content model (those components that can be contained in running text) has not been systematically defined. It is clear that this cannot be completely defined at this time. However, the model is designed to ensure that any element in the inline model may, in general, occur at any point in the content.

38. Some of the inline components are unlikely to have any implementation at this point in time. However, they have been identified as required for future use (such as the Semantic Tag component defined below). These are all grouped together in the document model as 'simple inline elements' and are considered to be generally interchangeable.

sect1.para: Metadata is used extensively in this model. Most components will either contain local or reference metadata.

listitem.para: 39. The metadata model has not yet been fully defined. Currently, we are assuming that the model will use some as yet undecided representation of RDF (W3C). Metadata content will be represented using a mixture of well-known vocabularies such as Dublin Core (Dublin Core Metadata Initiative), MODS (The Library Of Congress) and FOAF (The Friend of a Friend Project) along with taxonomies created by the OECD.

40. Metadata may be stored directly with the object being described or may be referenced. Direct metadata will be stored as a group of metadata items. Referenced metadata will be stored in the same XML file but will not be stored as a child of the object being described. The metadata will still be stored as a group of metadata items but will be referenced via an identifier attribute.

chapter.para: All components for the generic model are defined in the component catalogue. There are five groups of components (Semantic, Structural, Block, Inline and Metadata). Document types are based on a selection of components from the catalogue to create concrete document models for use in document creation.

listitem.para: 41. An abstract is found at the start of chapter like content (primarily articles and chapters themselves). The abstract of documents created using the current publication process may contain name, address and signature information. We consider that this is a rendering feature not an authoring feature and have not included it into this component.

42. The modelling workshop could not reach a clear consensus on the content model of an abstract although it was agreed that it should only consist of paragraph text. The number of paragraphs of text that could occur in an abstract could not be easily agreed. It was agreed that authors should be consulted.
43. During the first author workshop, it was made clear that an abstract should only consist of one paragraph of text. However, it was agreed that it would be possible for more than one to occur.

44. If the document has an executive summary it always occurs as the beginning of the document. It was agreed in the modelling meeting that the semantic definition of an executive summary is considerably simpler than the structural definition.

45. OECD guidelines state that an executive summary should consist of headings and paragraph text only. The modelling workshop felt that it might be wise to extend this to any block component as it was felt that ECO might wish to include charts and tables in the executive summary.

46. The current OECD style guide suggests a maximum of 2000 words for an executive summary. The first author interview (with authors from ENV) suggested that an executive summary could be of considerable length (up to eight pages being relatively common). However, the authors indicated that an executive summary would only ever contain headings and paragraph text.
47. For these reasons, we have currently modelled the executive summary as a group of block components.
48. Paragraph groups have been included in the model as a result of the document analysis process. A paragraph group consists of a set of related paragraphs of text with an optional heading.
49. Paragraph groups are an appropriate way to model semantic content such as legal content, as well as being a base for other types.
50. An author or editor's comment that annotates another component. Normally block level elements such as paragraphs and tables.

51. An introduction shares an identical structural role to a chapter. However, there are additional semantics. Conventionally, an introduction is considered part of the body of a document in contrast to a preface or foreword, which is not.

52. A preface differs from an introduction in that it is not part of the primary narrative of the document. A document may have more than one preface and each of those may have a different author (who is unlikely to be the primary author of the document) as identified by the modelling workshop.
53. Structurally a preface is identical to a chapter.

54. Appendices are much the same as a chapter except that they have added semantic impact. An appendix adds to or comments on the information contained in the main body of the document. Annexes do not need to be translated. Annexes and appendices are only differentiated by title. The document models use the term 'Appendix'.

55. Bibliographic content will generally be represent by citation components at the inline level. However, it is clear that some documents contain bibliographic content that is not based on citations within the text. For this reason, the document model contains a References component that contains MODS (The Library Of Congress) references. Groups of references and reference lists are to be specified in product definitions.

56. The modelling workshop identified that certain components (tables and figures especially) can contain arbitrary notes. We proposed a notes component to handle these notes. There is no apparent reason to restrict this component to tables and figures. Therefore, we have created this component as a standard block component in order to provide maximum flexibility.
57. The component consists of a wrapper and individual notes. Notes may contains any simple block structure such as paragraphs and tables.

58. Extracts represent one of two related inter document relationships. The first of these is embedding all or part of a document into the current document. This can range from a block quote (one or more paragraphs of text from an external source) from legislation in an official document to the inclusion of an entire official document as part of another official document. The second is linking where the content is not included into the reference document until the time at which it is rendered.
59. The conclusion of a document is generally a section. However, conclusions are identified as separate and modeled as a distinct component.
60. An agenda session represents a group of agenda items grouped together with a title and optional session specific metadata. Initially identified metadata includes time, location and duration.

61. An agenda item component represents a single item in an agenda. An initial agenda generally consists of a title along with some metadata and an optional Document List component. When an annotated agenda is created additional textual information and a time and duration are added to the item.

62. Document Lists are defined for use in agendas although there is no requirement that this be the case. Agenda items may have associated documents (official documents, room documents or almost any other document). When an agenda is annotated actions may be associated with those documents. The Document List contains one or more Document Reference components.

63. A Document Reference is a simplified citation. It contains a COTE or a document title only. In addition an Action component is allowed in order to represent an action to be taken on that reference.
64. An action is a simple text only component that describes the actions to be taken during a meeting with respect to a document for discussion.

65. These components generally have the same basic structure, as they are variations on the concept of a section. In the final, concrete, structure these components may be implemented sections with additional metadata. The modelling workshop reached the conclusion that it was preferable to include them as components in the model even if they were implemented as sections.
66. The definitions given below are those that are conventionally used rather than OECD specific definitions.

sect3.para: A volume is a grouping of documents that could stand alone. Volumes generally represent portions of very large publications that have been divided for publication or time sequenced publications that are grouped (perhaps by year – journals, for example).

listitem.para: 67. A part is a high level section that sits, hierarchically, between documents (the book equivalent level) and chapter level material such as chapters themselves, appendices and prefaces.

68. A chapter is the basic unit of published documents. Many official documents are chapters in that they are combined to create publications, each document becoming a chapter of the publication. A chapter may be the document itself, a standalone part of an official document
Chapters were identified as components of a document with no individual existence by Krzysztof Michalak (ENV/EPI) at the first author interview or simply a structural element within a document.
69. A section is the basic structural component of all OECD.Author documents.

70. The modelling workshop defined a section as a hierarchical component of a document with a title and text that could be considered a child. Sections may contain other sections and all block content.

71. In order to avoid ambiguity this component allows block content to occur in a section until the first sub section is created. Following that point, only subsections may be created. This ensures that the document model does not become ambiguous.

72. Components derived from the basic section will often add additional constraints to this component. Component defined by metadata area unlikely to add constraints whereas publishing components such as chapters and parts will almost always do so.
73. Nested and simple blocks are shown below:

sect1.para: Most of the content of any document consists of blocks of text.

sect3.para:
Paragraphs are the basic components for almost all content. We intend to introduce a content model that allows mixed content
Mixed content is the XML term for a mixture of text and elements as peers within another element. . The initial component will not define the elements that may occur within a paragraph. The logical document model defines a component type of 'Inline Components'. Any number (including zero) of inline components are valid within a paragraph.

listitem.para: 74. Paragraphs may occur in almost any context. Equally, almost any block may occur in the same context as a paragraph.
75. Formal paragraphs are simply standard paragraphs with a title. They can occur in almost all contexts where a standard paragraph may occur.

sect3.para: Paragraph groups are a simple structuring component used at block level. A paragraph group is a sequence of paragraphs (or formal paragraphs) with a title. No further structure is allowed.

listitem.para: 76. The modelling workshop concluded that lists are relatively simple components with obvious and distinct subtypes. Two of the subtypes have identical content models. The list component proposed here has fewer restrictions than that present in the current authoring environment. It is similar to that used in HTML and DocBook.

77. An ordered list has markers associated with each item that increment from one item to the next. AE2007 places rigid constrains on rendering of lists limiting the user to four styles and a maximum depth of five. There is no obvious reason for the limitation (and the document analysis found that the maximum depth in the sample was six – achieved using a standard Word list).
78. The document model will support unlimited nesting depth for lists. Business rules will be applied at the document type level to restrict this if required.

79. The rendering form for list markers needs to be represented in the component. In order to encourage consistency, a default style should be presented (managed at the document type level). Style hint information such as this must be inherited through the component. This implies that style metadata can be applied at multiple locations and used as appropriate.
80. Ordered lists must be able to restart numbering from the immediately preceding list at the same hierarchical level.

81. An itemized list has a single marker used for all elements within that list. As with ordered lists the AE2007 environment places a rigid constraint on the depth of the list. This constraint is relaxed in the content model as above.
82. Rendering rules for markers are applied exactly as above.

83. As is conventional, we have assumed that lists of both types will have identical content models. The list items can contain most of the paragraph equivalent blocks. In particular, list items may contain lists.

84. A definition list is a series of terms and definitions. This is often used to define lists of abbreviations or to explain jargon. It can be seen as a simple glossary. The term part of a definition list is a simple phrase and contains only inline content. The definition part of a definition list follows the standard list item definition above.

85. Tables are ubiquitous in OECD documents. Tables are currently modelled using a variant on the CALS Table Model (OASIS). In order to ensure that tables in the new document model are as compatible as possible with existing uses and with application interchange requirements we would suggest that the XML Exchange Table Model DTD (OASIS) be used as the OECD table model.

86. This was discussed in both the technical workshop (Corbas Consulting) and the modelling workshops and agreed as the basis for the model. The OASIS XML Exchange Model schema will be imported into the model within a wrapper component.

87. A graphic represents an external image and metadata about that image. An image may be a reference to external content such as a graphic file or it may be SVG (W3C) content. The metadata for a graphic includes source information and should normally be required.

88. A figure was defined in the modelling workshop as a graphic with additional semantics and content. The most important feature of a figure is the concept that it is a graphical representation of data. As such figures may contain metadata defining the data source (internal data source, external attributions, etc).
89. Additionally, figures may have sources (recorded via metadata), footnotes, explanatory notes and titles.

90. This component has an unusual role in the document model. The content model for a box is that of a section but is typed. However, the box itself fulfils a similar role to a paragraph. For this reason, after consultation with authors we have decided to treat it as a block component not a structural one.
91. Boxes are set off from the text in some way (usually by formatting with a border around it). When rendered to print the box location can be changed slightly for best presentation.

sect3.para: NB: Boxes have nested sections with semantic headings, if they are considered as a section the section is to group all subsections and allow for notes, footnotes and sources dedicated to the high level section.

listitem.para: 92. The link component is intended to act as a semantic placeholder for almost all types of link. Footnotes and citations are handled separately but otherwise, the link component represents both internal and external references. Clearly, this may not be the case at implementation level.

93. The OECD preference for the use of open standards and existing models suggests that the appropriate source for link mark-up should be the XLink specification (W3C). XLink is possibly not an appropriate approach for internal links as it requires the linked resource to be referenced as an IRI. A different approach may be required for internal link mark-up.

94. Semantic models of text normally do not provide any way of indicating formatting. The new OECD.Author document model must provide some way to indicate simple inline formatting requirements because the current AE2007 environment allows it. Therefore, the modelling workshop agreed that some sort of simple formatting must be allowed.

95. No decision on the implementation of this component has been decided. As formatting options are in many ways open ended, we suggest that a single formatting element would be advisable with the precise requested rendering indicated via properties (defined by a set of values taken from an enumerated list)
96. These components simply represent super and subscripted running text. They are not part of equations or note markers as those are rendering based.
97. The acronym component allows an abbreviation and its expansion to be simply marked up.

98. The phrase component allows a word or phrase to refer to metadata. This allows semantic enrichment to be applied if desired. For example, a piece of text could be marked with metadata indicating that it is a country name. Multiple metadata values may be associated with any given phrase. For simplicity, we envisage that metadata will be stored out of line in the document metadata.

99. The modelling workshop identified three potential approaches for chemical structures. All three of these are represented by the chemical structure component. We assume that one of the alternatives will be used.

100. Firstly, structures may be represented using XML from the Chemical Markup Language schema. Secondly, they may be represented as text conforming to the SMILES or OpenSMILES specifications. Finally, they may be represented as a graphic.
101. Chemical structures may occur as block components as well as inline components.
102. Four possible approaches for equations were also identified. All of these are represented by the equation component, any one of them being allowed within an equation element.

103. Equations may be represented as simple text using Unicode characters to represent the equation. Equations may also be represented as LaTeX content (this appears to be desired but no conclusion has been made as to whether it is useful). Ideally, equations will be represented as MathML mark-up. Ideally, content MathML should be used although presentation MathML would be acceptable. Finally, equations may be represented as a graphic.
104. Equations may occur as block components as well as inline components.

105. Indexes must be created from the content rather than the typeset pages. This separates the concepts of indexing from the requirements of printing. Therefore, the modelling workshop agreed an approach whereby words or phrases that are to be indexed should be indicated within the XML text.

106. The document model has taken the approach used by the DocBook project as the basis for the index component. This allows for three levels of index term, alternates (“see Other Concept”) and additional information (“see also Other Concept”).

107. The modelling workshop agreed that, in general, citation content should be stored out of line of the text, holding only a reference to the bibliographic data itself. It was agreed that bibliographic data should be stored in the Library of Congress MODS format (The Library Of Congress). Citations will store a reference to a bibliographic entry. In initial implementations all bibliographic entries will be stored in the document itself. It is envisaged that web services will be provide a look-up mechanism to provide consistency in future implementations.

108. Footnotes are to be stored inline at the point of first reference. A footnote may contain paragraph text only. This allows footnote rendering to be under the total control of the output mechanisms since no rendering assumptions are made. Footnotes must be identifiable to ensure that a single footnote may be referenced more than once. Footnotes are the only inline component that may contain paragraph content. Circular references have also been identified, but how this is enforced is to be defined.
109. A Duration component is simply a period of time. Currently, the document model allows these in two locations – as simple inlines and as part of the metadata for an agenda item.

110. A DateTime component allows a time and a date to be indicated in text. None of the semantics of a date are intended to represented, merely the indication that the text represents a date an/or time.

111. A metadata item contains information about the containing or referencing component. The model is currently completely open (allowing any component from any vocabulary). This will be refined as part of the initial implementation process as taxonomies are defined.
112. A metadata group contains multiple metadata items referring to the same component.

113. A paragraph or section may be numbered. In the OECD context, the review approach used by committees requires that numbering be tracked through the review process. This implies that numbers cannot simply be created based on sequence – it must be possible to indicate the previous number assigned to any paragraph or section. Current numbering of any given paragraph or section is predictable from the sequencing. However, the previous number must be stored in the metadata for that component.
114. It is envisaged that publishing content from a specific document model, in a specific media, is done by creating a Product Definition.

115. A Product Definition is a specific instance of a Product Profile, and defines the content that is to be published for a particular publishing event (e.g. Official Document) in a particular media (e.g. print).
116. Auto-generated and standalone textual components, such as – but not limited to – Table of Contents, Indexes and Copyright information, will be catered for in the product definition.

117. The initial schema based on model is inherently multilingual in that it uses the W3C xml:lang and xml:dir attributes at all levels in the document. However, it does not currently support alternative translations of a particular piece of content.

118. Manage document revisions/changes in multiple languages, specifically track changes, show/hide mark-up and/or from specific reviewers, accept/reject one/all revisions, previous/next revision, compare versions, etc.
119. Add semantic “security” meaning inline for subsequent process automation, e.g. document sanitising, prevention of publishing/dissemination of confidential text/components

120. Users must be able to access, view and potentially even reprocess the data in the archive throughout the entire record retention lifetime and beyond. Thus, in order to make data accessible for an undetermined length of time, it must be "normalized" in such a way that it can be easily understood outside the realm of any individual software system.

121. The metadata components defined in this report do not specify any metadata values. It is envisaged that appropriate directorates of the OECD will take responsibility for the creation of taxonomies for this purpose and that the KIM programme will own the overall OECD taxonomy.
122. OECD will be able use the GRDDL (W3C) specification to convert metadata aligned to the taxonomies to RDF.

123. This is a generic document type. All of the components modelled so far will be available in the standard document type. Documents are modelled as a container for metadata ad section based content. All other content is allowed via the section component.

sect1.para: Figure 31 – Doc Type: Document

listitem.para: 124. An article is a top-level document. Structurally, an article is almost identical to a chapter. It consists of an abstract and a series of sections. Articles may have appendices and bibliographies although it is unlikely that they will have a standalone Notes section as footnotes are generally rendered at the end of the article.
125. An agenda is one of the more specialised document types identified. The majority of the content of an agenda could be considered to be metadata.

126. OECD agendas can exist in two distinct incarnations. When an agenda is initially created it, it usually consists of a basic outline agenda, potentially listing sessions. At some time before a committee meeting the agenda is annotated with timelines and additional information. These are modelled identically with optional content added in the annotated agenda.

127. Much of the information in an agenda can be considered to be metadata (locations, times, people). As such these materials are a clear target for semantic enrichment. The initial model does not impose any semantic requirements.
128. There are currently two agenda models – simple and advanced. The difference between the two is simply whether or not an agenda is divided into multiple sessions.

sect1.para: Figure 33 – Doc Type: Simple Agenda
Figure 34 – Doc Type: Advanced Agenda

A publication is a collection of one or more documents, formatted for print or digital publication. Publications are often portmanteau documents and, therefore, have a more complex structure than standard documents. Structures that are not required in simpler documents are available (such as volumes and parts), along with additional metadata.

listitem.para: 129. The technical approach to the modelling was agreed in the technical workshop (Corbas Consulting). The model will be implemented using W3C Schemas version 1.0 (W3C). This approach was taken because W3C Schemas have a relatively high level of support amongst tools and applications. It was felt that DTDs were simply too archaic.

130. Validation requirements that cannot be expressed using the W3C schema syntax will be expressed using ISO Schematron. Schematron support should be a low cost approach since most of the tools and applications under consideration support XSLT and Schematron schemas are converted to XSLT for use.
131. It was agreed that a component based model would be used in order to encourage and facilitate reuse to the greatest extent possible.

132. Reuse will primarily occur through the use of the W3C schema substitutionGroup method and the use of grouping where appropriate. The use of substitution groups allows us to create open-ended models.

133. The model will be defined using global types and elements based on those types. These will be aggregated to create document models. Whilst this approach leads to a larger and more complex schema, it allows for considerably higher degrees of reuse than a simple element based model and makes modification and update of the schema much simpler.
134. Where it is necessary to assert content requirements that cannot be expressed using W3 schemas, Schematron

sect1.para: This is a non-exclusive list of OECD document types. Additional types will be added to this list as they are discovered.
Defined by ITN/CIS from document analysis:

listitem.para: Country Review-Study
Summary Record/Minutes
Statistical Annex
Mandate
Minutes
Case Study
Briefing
Committee Report
Report to Council
Narrative Document

sect1.para: Proposed during document assembler workshop:

listitem.para: Working Paper
Chairs Summary

Policy Briefing
We need to determine how a Policy Briefing differs from a Briefing as they were identified separately.
Glossary
OECD Legal Instruments
Guideline
Handbook
Manual
Code
Articles (see below)
Surveys & Questionnaires

sect1.para: Proposed during author interviews

listitem.para: Highlights – similar to a policy brief (proposed by Krzysztof Michalak of ENV/EPI)
Project Proposal/Scoping paper (proposed by Nils-Axel Baathen of ENV/EEI)

sect1.para: The following is a list of areas that must still be determined

listitem.para: Namespace policy
Metadata format
Extent of version and source tracking

chapter.para: The following workshops have been held during the modelling process.

sect1.para: Date: 20 October 2011

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Nigel Wilkie (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Valerie Delahouliere (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Marion Desmartin (PAC/PROD)
Mary-Ann Grosset (EXD/OPS/IMSD)
Thierry Vebr (EXD/OPS/IMSD)

sect1.para: The purpose of this meeting was to present the project plan and approach. A summary of the meeting can be found in Sharepoint here.
Date: 20 October 2011
The purpose of this workshop was to confirm and correct the initial set of document types and components defined through document analysis.
Participants:

listitem.para: Delphine Grandrieux (NEA/RE)
Jill Gibb (ENV/EHS)
Katherine Kraig-Ernandes (PAC/ED)
Edward Smiley (DAF)
Celia Rutkoski (ECO/SSD)
Shayne Maclachlan (ENV/EPI)
Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Nigel Wilkie (EXD/ITN/CIS)

sect1.para: A summary of the workshop is available in Sharepoint here.
Date: 25 October 2011
The purpose of this workshop was to define technical strategies and approaches to the modelling process. The workshop discussed XML schema technologies and model governance issues.
Participants:

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Joseph Crowther (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Jakob Fix (PAC/PS)
Claudia Tromboni (PAC/PP)
Erik Laading (PAC/ED)
Thierry Vebr (EXD/OPS/IMSD)

sect1.para: A summary of the workshop is available in Sharepoint here.
Dates: 9 November 2011 and 21 November 2011

The purpose of the modelling workshops was to define and agree the model components and the relationships between them. The potential document components were discussed and the relationships and structure defined.
The body of this document is the result of those workshops.
Participants (not all attended both workshops):

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Joseph Crowther (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Jakob Fix (PAC/PS)
Erik Laading (PAC/ED)
Thierry Vebr (EXD/OPS/IMSD)
Nigel Wilkie (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Valerie Delahouliere (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Marion Desmartin (PAC/PROD)
Mary-Ann Grosset (EXD/OPS/IMSD)
Simone Sergi (EXD)
Pascale Cissokho-Mutter (PAC/PM)

sect1.para: Date: 8 December 2011

The templating workshop presented and discussed proposed input and output templates for the initial document models. The workshop also discussed potential changes to the styling of official documents and the governance of document styling in future.
Participants:

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Nigel Wilkie (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Valerie Delahouliere (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Patrick Pauly (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Angel Alonso Arroba (SGE)
Lucy Hullett (ELS/MSU)
Susan Peric (STI/MSU)
Béatrice Nivet (EXD/OPS/IMSD)
Marlène Mohier (ELS/MSU)
Isabelle Renaud (SGE)

sect1.para: A summary of this workshop is available in Sharepoint here.
Date: 9 December 2011
The purpose of this meeting was to introduce the modelling project to authors, obtain feedback on the current state of the model and to discover any issues that might be resolved using the new model.
Participants:

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Krzysztof Michalak (ENV/EPI)
Nils-Axel Braathen (ENV/EEI)

sect1.para: A summary of this interview is available in Sharepoint here.
Date: 16 December 2011
This meeting was convened in order to ensure that both KIM and ITN were in agreement on the metadata storage requirements of the document model.
Participants

listitem.para: Nic Gibson (EXD/ITN/CIS, Corbas Consulting)
Valerie Delahouliere (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Nigel Wilkie (EXD/ITN/CIS)
Thierry Vebr (EXD/OPS/IMSD)

sect1.para: A summary of this workshop is available in Sharepoint here.

chapter.para: PAC requested that a comparison with NarrDoc version 1.7.3 was undertaken. The table below shows the results of the comparison. Changes were made to the model where we realized that NarrDoc contained components that had not been discovered during the workshop process.

entry.para: Bilingual documents would be indicated by elements indicating that they were in multiple languages
Taxonomy to be defined. We may wish to revisit author as metadata and consider it as content

Bibliographics tools will be added at the application level, so not authored inline. Modelling workshop agreed on use of MODS for bibliographic content. May have to be revisited for non cited content in bibliographies and suggest that we use MODS explicitly in the model. MODS 3.4 to the schema directory tree but not integrated it at this time.
The authoring environment does not distinguish publishing structures such as body
Sample files are required to be able to work on the ‘type’ attribute.
Could be created as a separate element if needed
Need examples to properly understand NarrDoc here
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
OECD.Author equation model is richer - this will be a potential transformation issue
OECD.Author treats this as simplified section model (a block group to be exact).
Outer structure is collapsed, all that remains is the title and subtitle.
OECD.Author does not distinguish between forewards and prefaces except via the title
OECD.Author has a slightly different graphical model but the match is close enough
All headings are represented using the oecdTitleGroup component which contains title, subtitle, shortitle
Also most elements support the XLink model so almost any element can express linking semantics
The design of the OECD.Author environment requires all links to use URI syntax and be resolveable so this is not required
Considerably richer than the NarrDoc model, transformation will discard information.

In an authoring environment, a document is, by definition, in its original language (indicated using xml:lang attributes). However, if it were necessary to refer to an original language metadata would be used.
Note - listItem has two content models depending on the parent element (ordered or itemized lists). Also listItem is used in definitionList elements
In generic documents this is the root element, in more specialised models (e.g. agendas) it may not be
The model supports two distinct paragraph types, normal and formal (with a title).
This is a formatting control and not in the scope of the document model.
Modelling of components above the level of chapter need further definition and agreement.
The model is slightly richer since OECD.Author lists have optional titles
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
Inline text with punctuation for now, should be modelled as inline quote of type Extract in future.
The attribution element is identical to the metadata element but is used to separately identify source information). It may be replaced with the generic Metadata component in a later version.
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
Light MathML implemementation using display model for mapping to specchar
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
The model does not wrap headings in another element.
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
Not sure the mapping is 100% accurate but any revision required will be very minor
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
All CALS components supported via extensible CALS implementation
Linking model is based on XLink so linking attributes and terminology are the same across all elements that supporting linkage (most elements)

sect1.para: Numbered paragraphs, sections and lists all have a shared attribute set which supports numbering styles, overrides and continuation from the preceding item or restarts.

sect2.para: Two additional components were identified during the comparison exercise and have been added to the model.

sect3.para: The acknowledgements component has been added to the model. This is modeled as a paragraph group in order to allow some simple structure.
The title component has been extended with a short title attribute consisting of text only. It is not thought that this title will be used for general display purposes.
